titleStmt.title: Microstructures and mechanical properties of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y (x + y = 4) multi-component alloys

analytic.title: Microstructures and mechanical properties of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y (x + y = 4) multi-component alloys

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Multi-component alloy Microstructures Mechanical properties Bonding behavior

div.p: In order to reveal the effect of homogenization treatment on the phase composition and chemical distribution of MoNbTa-based refractory multi-component alloys, the microstructures and mechanical properties of as-cast and homogenized (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y (x + y = 4) alloys were investigated by using X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy and mechanics performance tests. Besides, the theoretical elastic properties and bonding behavior were analyzed by the first principle calculations. The results show that except for (MoNbTa) 6 Ti 2.5 V 1.5 alloy, there are no obvious differences of crystal structures between other as-cast and homogenizing alloys. The lattice constants of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys increase with the increase of Ti content, while the lattice constants of alloys decrease after homogenization treatment. Typically (Mo, Ta)-rich dendritic and (Ti, V)-rich interdendritic morphologies are observed, and the atoms would diffuse during the homogenization process resulting in the uniform composition. The as-cast (MoNbTa) 6 Ti 2 V 2 alloy exhibit the largest values of compressive strength, plasticity, and hardness in these alloys. Following homogenization, the mechanical properties of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys decrease significantly. The results of first principles reveal that the covalent bonding interactions between Ti and V atoms are stronger than that between Mo and Ta atoms in these MoNbTa-based refractory multicomponent alloys.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In 2004, Cantor [1] and Yeh [2] independently proposed the basic concept of multi-principal element alloys at the same time. The multicomponent alloys, which are also known as high-entropy alloys (HEAs), are originally defined as an alloy consisting of five or more elements, each elements with a molar content between 5 and 35 at. % [3][4][5][6]. The high entropy alloys have many special properties which are different from traditional alloys. This is due to four core effects, namely: high-entropy effects in thermodynamics, sluggish diffusion in kinetics, severe lattice distortion in structures, and cocktail effects in properties [7]. At present, the widely studied high entropy alloy systems can be generally divided into two categories: one is the traditional high entropy alloy system which is mainly mixed with the IV periodic elements (Al, Cr, Co, Fe, Mn, Ni, Ti, etc.) [8][9][10]. The other type is the refractory high entropy alloys (RHEAs) made by mixing elemental elements with high melting point (Cr, Hf, Mo, Nb, Ta, Ti, V, W, etc.) [11].

The refractory high entropy alloys usually forms the solid solutions with single phase body centered cubic (BCC) structure, or precipitates the second phase on the BCC matrix [12][13][14]. In addition to the traditional HEAs, the refractory high-entropy alloys may have better high temperature properties because most of the elements used for this alloys are metallic elements with higher melting point. The effect of Al content on the microstructures and properties of refractory high entropy alloys was studied by O. N. Senkov et al., and it is found that AlMo 0.5 Nb-Ta 0.5 TiZr and Al 0.4 Hf 0.6 NbTaTiZr RHEAs exhibit extremely high strength at room temperature, with the compressive yield strength reaching more than 2000 MPa [15]. This is mainly due to the solid solution strengthening of different alloying elements.

The typical dendritic morphologies are usually observed in the ascast RHEAs, and there are compositions differences between dendritic (DR) and interdendritic (ID) regions. The proper homogenization treatment can make the atomic diffusion and the microstructures more uniform. Chen H. et al. studied the effect of heat treatment temperature on the microstructures and mechanical properties of NbMoCrTiAl refractory high entropy alloy, and found that the microstructures of the alloy changed from dendritic to equiaxed morphologies when alloy was annealed at 1300 • C for 20 h in an argon protected environment [16]. Meanwhile, the formation of Laves phase (Cr 2 Nb) with the hexagonal structure can be effectively inhibited. The homogenization treatment can not only make the microstructures uniform but also improve properties of the alloy. It is found by Shi Y. Z. et al. that after homogenization at 1250 • C, the corrosion resistance of Al x CoCrFeNi alloy in 3.5% NaCl solution was improved [17]. Following homogenization, the fracture strength of AlFeNiCuCr HEA increases from 1643 MPa to 1799 MPa [18].

In order to form stable solid solutions for the high entropy alloys, the elements with similar basic properties such as atomic radius and crystal structures are usually selected as components. For alloying elements with high melting points higher than 2700 • C, Mo, Nb, and Ta elements exhibit the relatively close atomic radii. Therefore, the refractory high entropy alloys containing Mo, Nb, and Ta elements are considered to have excellent high temperature properties, and have been extensively studied. For example, MoNbTaTiVAl x [19], MoNbTaV x [20], MoN-bTaWX (X = Cr, Zr, V, Hf and Re) [21], and MoNbTaWTi x [22], etc.. In this work, a series of novel MoNbTa-based refractory multi-component alloys was designed and prepared, in which Ti and V elements were added. The aim of this work was to investigate the microstructures and mechanical properties of these MoNbTa-based multi-component alloys. In particular, the effect of homogenization treatment on the phase composition and chemical distribution was discussed. Besides, the relationship between the mechanical properties of alloys and bonding behavior of elements was analyzed according to the first principle calculations. These results might provide useful guidance for the development of multi-component alloys in high-melting-point alloy fields.

div.head: Alloy preparation and characterization
div.p: A series of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y (x + y = 4, x = 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3) multicomponent alloys ingots, which are referred to as Ti1V3, Ti1.5 V2.5, Ti2V2, Ti2.5 V1.5 and Ti3V1 alloys respectively, were prepared by WK-Π vacuum arc melting furnace, and the metals Mo, Nb, Ta, Ti, and V with a high purity (≥99.5%) were chosen for raw materials in this experiment. The (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys ingots were designed according to the corresponding atomic molar ratio, and were smelted under the protection of a Ti-gettered high purity argon. In order to ensure full mixing of the compositional elements, the ingots were re-melted in a water-cooled Cu crucible repeatedly four times. The as-cast alloy ingots were homogenized at 1000 • C for 4 h, and then furnace cooled to room temperature using a box type resistance furnace. For investigation on the microstructures and mechanical properties of alloys, the X-ray diffraction (XRD; XRD-700S), which uses Cu K α radiation scanning from 20 to 80 • with a speed of 5 • /min, was introduced to identify the crystal structures of the alloys. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Zeiss-Sigma) with the energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) was used to investigate microstructures and chemical compositions of alloys, and tested samples were electrolytically etched by 6% HClO 4 + 14% H 2 O + 80% C 2 H 5 OH (percent by volume) before microstructures observations for SEM. The cylindrical samples with dimensions Φ 4 mm × 6 mm were conducted for testing the room compressive properties using the WEW-200 materials universal testing machine with a deformation rate of 1.0 mm/min. The HVS-1000c Vickers hardness tester under a load of 49 N for 15 s was used for hardness measurements.

div.head: The first principle calculation
div.p: The elastic properties and bonding behavior of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys were calculated by the first principles method, which is based on the density functional theory (DFT). In this calculation work, in order to describe the interaction between the electron and ion of alloying atoms, the ultra-soft pseudo-potential [23] was used. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) of Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) parameters [24,25] were adopted for describing the exchange and correlation terms. The cutoff energies of 400 eV were used to ensure precision. The suitable grids for the k-point meshes were based on the Monkhorst-Pack scheme [26]. The following convergence conditions were utilized for these calculations: the maximum force on the atom is lower than 0.01 eV/Å, the maximum displacement between cycles is lower than 5.0 × 10 -4 Å, the maximum stress is lower than 0.02 GPa, and total energy changes on each atom are lower than 5.0 × 10 -6 eV/atom. All the first principle calculations were carried out in the Cambridge Sequential Total Energy Package (CASTEP) code. The modeling of crystal structures in this work refers to the results of experiments, and will be described in the following section.

Based on the evaluation on the change of total energy with lattice deformation, the elastic constants which reflect the resistance of a crystal to an externally applied stress can be calculated by following [27]:
div.formula: U = ΔE V 0 = 1 2 ∑ 6 i ∑ 6 j C ij e i e j (1
div.p: where ΔE is energy variations, while V 0 is volume of the unit cell. C ij are components of the elasticity tensor, and e i and e j are applied strains. The polycrystalline structural properties of alloy including bulk modulus B, shear modulus G, Young's modulus E and Poisson's ratio ν can be estimated by the Voigt-Reuss-Hill (V-R -H) approximations based on the obtained single-crystal elastic constants as following [28]:
div.formula: B = B V + B R 2 ; G = G V + G R 2 ; E = 9BG 3B + G ; ν = 3B -E 6B(2)
div.p: where subscripts V and R mean for corresponding modulus, respectively. The Voigt and Reuss bounds for bulk modulus B can be calculated by Eq. ( 3), and the Voigt and Reuss bounds for shear modulus G can be calculated by Eq. ( 4)
here C ij is the single-crystal elastic constants, while S ij refers to the elastic compliances of materials.

div.head: Microstructures and phase compositions
div.p: Fig. 1 shows the a comparison between X-ray diffraction patterns of the as-cast and homogenized (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys. It can be identified that all as-cast alloys are composed of a single solid solution with BCC structure. Following homogenizing, except for Ti2.5 V1.5 alloy, the phase compositions of these homogenized alloys are maintained. A new precipitated phase is observed in the homogenized Ti2.5 V1.5 alloy. This unknown phase is presumed to be Ta 2 V according to the additional diffraction peaks. In addition, with the increase of Ti content, the diffraction peaks of BCC phase all shift toward the left as compared to those of corresponding as-cast and homogenized alloy, which indicates that the lattice constants of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys show an upward trend (as shown in Fig. 2). For as-cast (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloy, the lattice constant of alloys goes from 3.196 Å to 3.231 Å based on the Bragg formula when the content of Ti increases from 10 at.% to 30 at.%.

Regarding homogenized alloys, it is noted that obvious shift of diffraction peaks to the right with respect to corresponding as-cast alloy is found, implying the decrease of lattice constants. This may be due to the elimination of defects in the alloys after homogenization, resulting in alleviating the lattice distortion of alloys.

Though crystal structures of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys are basically the same in the as-cast and homogenized states, there are some differences in phase morphologies between them. Fig. 3 shows the SEM images of as-cast and homogenized (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys. It is clearly seen that typically dendritic (DR) and interdendritic (ID) morphologies of high entropy alloys are found in all as-cast and homogenized alloys. With the increase of Ti content, the dendritic morphologies of as-cast alloys become coarser. After homogenization, the microstructures of alloys are not simply coarsened, but show a kind of irregularity. Take Ti1V3 alloy for example, the microstructures images in Fig. 3b show much coarser than as-cast ones (Fig. 3a). Regarding Ti3V1 alloy (Fig. 3i andj), the dendritic morphologies change from massive to dendritic structures after homogenization. Specially, both massive and dendritic morphologies are observed simultaneously in the homogenized Ti2.5 V1.5 alloy. The irregular morphologies of the homogenized alloys are probably caused by the redistribution of elements between DR and ID regions, which is resulted from the diffusion of alloying elements during the heat treatment.

According to the EDS results of as-cast and homogenized (MoN-bTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys in Table 1, the chemical compositions and element diffusion are revealed briefly. According to SEM-EDS analysis, the actual compositions of as-cast and homogenized alloys are in good agreement with the nominal ones. The DR regions are enriched with Mo and Ta, while Ti and V are more easily enriched in the ID regions. After homogenization, the elements segregation still exists, but the distribution of the elements is much more uniform than that of the as-cast state. Take Ti2V2 alloy as an example, as shown in Fig. 4, the results of elements distribution indicate that Nb element presents relatively uniform between DR and ID regions in as-cast and homogenized Ti2V2 alloy. The aggregation of Ta is obvious in DR regions, while the ID regions are enriched with Ti and V. The segregation of elements for Ti2V2 alloy is alleviated by homogenization treatment to some extent (seen in Fig. 4 (b)), especially for Ta, Ti and V elements. There is no significant difference between the distribution of elements on the DR and ID boundaries, which implies that the atoms would diffuse during the homogenization process resulting in the uniform composition.

div.head: Mechanical properties
div.p: The room temperature compression tests were carried out to investigate the mechanical properties of the as-cast and homogenized (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys, and Fig. 5 shows the corresponding engineering stress vs strain curves. Except for Ti1V3 alloy, the distinct elastic deformation, yielding, and destruction phases during compression process are clearly observed in the as-cast (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys, and these alloys all exhibit compressive yield strengths of about 1100 MPa. Particularly, the as-cast Ti2V2 alloy has the largest values of compressive strength (1480 MPa) and plasticity (10.9%) in (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys. It suggests that for the as-cast (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys, the equal molar ratio of each compositions is more beneficial to the mechanical properties of the alloys. The strength and plasticity of Ti2V2 alloys decrease gradually with the increase of Ti content, while there is a sharp decrease in strength and plasticity of Ti2V2 alloys decrease sharply with the increase of V content.

Comparing with as-cast alloys, the strength and plasticity of (MoN-bTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys decrease significantly after homogenization. In addition to the homogenized Ti2.5 V1.5 and Ti3V1 alloys, which can maintain the compressive yield strength and partial plasticity in the ascast state, the others alloys have been transformed into brittle materials after homogenization. The reason for this may be that the distribution of alloying elements in DR and ID tends to be uniform when the alloys are homogenized, which breaks the dendrite structures composed of hard ID phase (Ti and V segregation) and soft DR phase (Ta and Mo segregation) in the initial as-cast state. It results in the decrease of the strength and plasticity of the homogenized (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys. Of course, further experiments are needed to verify this conjecture. Fig. 6 is the hardness change curves the as-cast and homogenized (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys with the change of Ti content. It is seen that compared with a high content of Ti, the hardness of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys is stronger with a high content of V, and as-cast Ti2V2 alloy has a maximum Vickers hardness of 600 among these as-cast and homogenized (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys. Regarding with homogenized (MoN-bTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys, the hardness values of the alloys with different Ti contents are basically the same, and are slightly lower than those in ascast. This is most likely due to the easing of segregation of alloying elements and the release of internal stress caused by the solidification process after homogenization treatment.

div.head: Theoretical elastic properties and bonding behavior
div.p: The experimental results show that the mechanical properties of the (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys are related to the compositions. Since almost all alloys (except for Ti2.5 V1.5 alloy) form single-phase solid solutions, the theoretical elastic properties and bonding behavior of alloys can be calculated by the first principles, thus the micro-mechanism of mechanical properties of alloys can be explained. For the convenience of modeling for crystal structures, all (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys are treated as single-phase solid solutions with body centered cubic (BCC) structure. Therefore, simple supercells based on the BCC unit cell are adopted to build the crystal structures of the single-phase (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys, in which the nearest neighbor atoms were set as Mo and Ta atoms, or Ti and V atoms, and the Nb atoms were distributed randomly, referring to the results of EDS.

The equilibrium crystal structures of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys with single-phase BCC solid solutions were calculated, and then the corresponding equilibrium lattice constants were obtained, as shown in Fig. 2. The obtained lattice constants by the first principle method are all consistent with the values calculated by XRD diffraction patterns, and show deviations not more than 1%. It indicates that the established crystal structures are reliable, and these calculations are of high precision.

Based on obtained equilibrium crystal structures, the elastic constants C ij of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys, which reflect the ability of the crystal resisting the applied stress, were calculated and shown in Fig. 7. It is noted that the values of elastic constants C 11 , C 22 and C 33 generally present a downward trend as the increase of Ti content, which implies the ability that (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys resists external uniaxial compression along the x and z axes would weaken due to the declining values of C 11 and C 33 with the increase of Ti content.

The Theoretical elastic properties of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys with single-phase BCC structure, including the bulk modulus B, shear modulus G, and Young's modulus E, can obtained by using the Voigte-Reusse-Hill (V-R-H) approximations. Fig. 8 is the corresponding Ti content dependences of calculated B, G, and E for (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys, in which we can see that the values calculated by the methods of Voigte, Reusse, and Hill are close to each other. The bulk modulus B, which reflects the ability that structure resists volume change under external compression, presents a trend of gradual decline with the increase of Ti content. Regarding the shear modulus G, and Young's modulus E, there is a same trend of change that goes up and then goes down, and the maximum values of G and E are all presented when the composition ratio of alloys is equal molar ratio. In other words, the Ti2V2 alloy has the best ability that resists reversible deformations in the direction of shear stress than other alloys, and meanwhile, Ti2V2 alloy is considered to be the stiffer material than the others due to the larger value of E. In addition, based on calculated bulk modulus B and shear modulus G, the theoretical hardness H v for (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys with single-phase BCC structure can easily evaluated by following empirical equation [29]:

Based on the calculated values of bulk modulus B, shear modulus G by the method of Hill in Fig. 8, the theoretical hardness H v for (MoN-bTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys were evaluated and shown in Fig. 6. Considering that the Ti2.5 V1.5 alloy would precipitate the second phase experimentally (seen in Fig. 1), while the single-phase solid solution were adopted in the first principle calculations. Therefore, the value of predicted hardness H v for Ti2.5 V1.5 alloy will be difficult to compare and discuss here. Except for Ti2.5 V1.5 alloy, the variation law of the predicted hardness value is in good agreement with the experimental results, and Ti2V2 alloy exhibits the largest hardness in these alloys. It indicates that our calculations have good reliability.

Referring to the conclusions of previous references and our results of the EDS analysis, Mo and Ta are enriched in the DR regions, and the ID regions are enriched with Ti and V. In our calculations, the nearest neighbor atoms were set as Mo and Ta atoms, or Ti and V atoms for the crystal structures modeling of single-phase BCC (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys to better simulate the actual situation. Hence, the elastic properties of alloys can be analyzed by investigating the bonding behavior of the nearest neighbor atoms. Fig. 9 shows the calculated average bonding overlap population and length of Mo -Ta and Ti -V bonding. It can be easily seen that the atomic bonding length of Mo and Ta is between 2.81 Å and 2.82 Å, while the bonding length between Ti and V (from 2.71 Å to 2.77 Å) is smaller. It implies that the bonding between Ti and V atoms would be stronger than that between Mo and Ta. The results about the bonding overlap population can provide evidence for such a conclusion. Generally speaking, a bonding-type interaction between atoms is confirmed when the value of overlap population is positive, and higher values of bonding overlap population correspond to stronger covalent interactions between atoms. The results shown in Fig. 9 clearly indicate that the covalent interactions between Ti and V atoms are stronger than that between Mo and Ta atoms. It can be speculated that breaking the bonding between Ti and V atoms is more difficult, resulting in higher hardness in ID phases that are enriched with Ti and V [30]. When the values of bonding overlap population of Mo -Ta and Ti -V are close to each other, the hardness of the alloy would be higher, while the hardness of the alloy is smaller when the difference of bonding overlap population between these two bonding is larger. This can provide reference for the prediction of hardness of alloy to a certain extent. Combined with the experimental results, the distribution of the elements for homogenized (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys is much more uniform than that of the as-cast state, which causes the bonding behavior between atoms to be affected. The bonding overlap population and volume of Mo-Ta and Ti -V are changed at the same time. This explains the reason that the hardness of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys are basically the same after homogenization treatment. Of course, in order to further analyze the bonding behavior of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys before and after homogenization, it is necessary to establish crystal structures closer to the experimental atomic distributions in the future work.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: The (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y (x + y = 4) multi-component alloys were prepared by vacuum arc melting, and the microstructures and mechanical properties of as-cast and homogenized alloys have been investigated. The following conclusions can be obtained in this work:

1. Except for homogenized Ti2.5 V1.5 alloy, all as-cast and homogenized alloys are composed of a single solid solution with BCC structure. With the increase of Ti content, the lattice constants of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys increase. Meanwhile, the lattice constants of homogenized alloys decrease with respect to corresponding as-cast alloy. 2. All as-cast and homogenized alloys form typically (Mo, Ta)-rich dendritic and (Ti, V)-rich interdendritic morphologies of high entropy alloys. The dendritic morphologies of as-cast alloys become coarser with the increase of Ti content, while the microstructures of homogenized alloys show a kind of irregularity. 3. For the mechanical properties of as-cast (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys, the addition of Ti element is better than that of V element, and the as-cast Ti2V2 alloy shows the largest values of compressive strength, plasticity, and hardness in these alloys. After homogenization, mechanical properties of (MoNbTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys decrease significantly. 4. The results of the first principle calculations show that with the increase of Ti content, the theoretical elastic constants C 11 , C 22 and C 33 present a downward trend, and there is a same trend of change that goes up and then goes down for Young's modulus E. In addition, the bonding behavior between Ti and V atoms present a stronger the covalent interactions than that between Mo and Ta atoms in (MoN-bTa) 6 Ti x V y alloys.
